title: An LVMH Takeover of Tiffany Could Expand the Global Reach of Little Blue Box
text:
Text size

If LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton successfully folds Tiffany & Co. into its upscale portfolio, consumers are not likely to see many immediate changes, perhaps just the convenience of shopping for Tiffany-branded jewelry and watches from LVMH-owned stores around the world, experts say.

A takeover of Tiffany, the iconic New York jeweler, would help strengthen the French conglomerate’s position in the jewelry and watch market by leveraging Tiffany’s brand to a cohort of its high-end consumers, says Kate Newlin, chief executive of the New York-based eponymous business management consulting firm.

“It makes no difference to consumers overall,” Newlin says, “However, it is an evolving case study. My bet is there will be Tiffany boutiques—featuring jewelry and a corporate gift section—within larger LVMH stores.”

LVMH encompasses 75 upscale brands, including Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior, Sephora, Givenchy, Fendi, and Bulgari. And all the major brands have stores globally.

This past weekend, news leaked that LVMH approached Tiffany with a takeover offer of $120 a share in cash. Both companies confirmed they were in preliminary discussions about a cash buyout.

“There can be no assurance that these discussions will result in any agreement,” LVMH said in a press release Monday.

Meanwhile, Tiffany said its board of directors is reviewing the unsolicited proposal “to determine the course of action it believes is in the best interests of the company and its shareholders.”

Both companies didn’t respond to requests for further comment.

The LVMH Group’s jewelry and watch lineup, currently including brands such as Bulgari, Hublot, and TAG Heuer, mainly competes with Cartier—a subsidiary of Switzerland-based Richemont Group—and Tiffany.

This business unit only brought in about 9% of LVMH’s overall revenue in the first quarter of 2019. Meanwhile, fashion and leather goods accounted for almost half of the total quarterly revenue of €12.5 billion (US$13.9 billion), according to the company’s quarterly filings. The company’s annual revenue in 2018 was close to €46.8 billion.

However, jewelry is the fastest-growing business within the luxury sector overall. In 2018, the global jewelry market grew 7% and was worth about €18 billion, according to Bain & Co., a global management consultancy.

“ While investors know Tiffany for silver jewelry, the reality is that it is very adjacent to Cartier, notably with mainland Chinese consumers. ” —Erwan Rambourg

“Were the bid for Tiffany to go through, it would increase the separation between LVMH and competitors,” said Erwan Rambourg, global co-head of consumer and retail at HSBC, in a client note. “While investors know Tiffany for silver jewelry, the reality is that it is very adjacent to Cartier, notably with mainland Chinese consumers.”

In the past years, the 182-year-old Tiffany has pushed an expansion into China, with plans to open stores in several major cities. Its flagship New York store on Fifth Avenue has been renovated to include a restaurant decorated with its iconic Robin’s egg blue colors, to be more immediately associated with the famed movie Breakfast at Tiffany’s.

“Tiffany is now more about the ‘T’ brand, the blue color, and the experiential breakfast, which is auspicious to appeal to a broader consumer group, especially international tourists,” Newlin says.

With skyrocketing costs of real estate for luxury retail, Tiffany needs an infusion of money and support, she says.

On the other hand, large LVMH stores are also underperforming. “If you got a marque name like Tiffany, luxury customers do want to come to,” she says.

Founded in 1837 by jeweler Charles Lewis Tiffany, and expanded under the artistic direction of his son, Louis Comfort Tiffany, Tiffany & Co. was sold to Avon Products Inc. for about US$104 million in November 1978. In August 1984, Avon sold Tiffany to an investor group led by William R. Chaney for US$135.5 million in cash. Tiffany went public in 1987.

The company has an annual revenue of US$4 billion. LVMH’s US$120-per-share offer values the company at US$14.5 billion. At Tuesday’s close, Tiffany was trading at US$126.8 a share, up from US$98.55 on Friday.

A fair valuation of the jeweler would be about US$160 a share or higher, according to Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen. He wrote in a note that Tiffany’s “strategic positioning as a gifting authority, brand DNA as a diamond and bridal authority, are leading qualities and deserve an exceptional premium.”

HSBC estimates that US$135 a share “would be enough to convince the Tiffany board and holders to accept LVMH’s bid,” the bank’s clients’ note said.

In any case, Tiffany would be one of the biggest acquisitions by Bernard Arnault, LVMH’s chief executive and controlling shareholder. The 70-year-old is the third-richest person in the world, with a net worth over US$100 billion.
description: The famed New York-based jewelry brand could be traveling to luxury stores around the world if a sale happens
